channel.title: python on looking at numbers
channel.description: Recent content in python on looking at numbers

item.title: Using Anaconda
item.description: Install Anaconda There seems to be two main ways to handle python packaging, pip with pipenv and conda. I’ve gone with conda, though it turns out I often have to use pip inside conda. Anyways, there is a cheatsheet, but here’s all I use: download and install anaconda from here. restart terminal and check anaconda is in the path by ECHO $SHELL If its not in the path then:

item.title: PyCon Australia 2018
item.description: My notes for the PyConAU 2018 talks I went to. How Python saved a rescue dog - a foster fail story Lighting Macro Photographs with CircuitPython Writing fast and efficient MicroPython Asyncio in MicroPython Demystifying LoRaWAN with PyCom Workplace Environment Sensing with Python Automating Your Home with Python, Raspberry Pi and Homekit Education Seminar Student Showcase Keynote: Annie Parker on Techfugees Describing Descriptors What is the most common street name in Australia?

item.title: Advent of Code 2016
item.description: Notes for the Advent of Code 2016 programming challange. Advent of Code is a series of small programming puzzles for a variety of skill levels. They are self-contained and are just as appropriate for an expert who wants to stay sharp as they are for a beginner who is just learning to code. Each puzzle calls upon different skills and has two parts that build on a theme.

item.title: deeplearning.ai: Neural Networks and Deep Learning
item.description: It had been a while since I finished Udacity’s Deep Learning course, so as a refresher I signed up for Andrew NG’s deeplearning.ai course. These are my notes for the first course in the series: Neural Networks and Deep Learning. Course Resources Discussion forum YouTube playlist for Course 1 course reviews: 1 Week 1: Introduction A basic NN looks at housing price prediction, can use simple regression

item.title: Notes for Harvard's Cs109 data science class
item.description: These are my notes for Harvard’s 2015 CS109 class, which i went through with Sydney Machine Learning’s study group from Ausgust to October 2017 at Amazon Web Service’s sydney office. Why CS109? This class was recommended at Quora and a few other places as being a good resource for practical data science, so here goes. These notes are updated as I work through the course syllabus and the labs and homeworks.

item.title: Udacity ND101: Deep Learning Nanodegree
item.description: My notes & files for Udacity’s Deep Learning intro course. Before the course starts: Read Machine learning is fun Watch Andrew NG: Deep Learning in Practice (34 minutes) Go though UD730 deep learning course on Udacity Watch Learn tensorflow 3 hour video http://rodneybrooks.com/patrick-winston-explains-deep-learning/ Python resources The course recommneds knowing basic python from here, but I found the following two resources better: A whirlwind tour of Python Python Data Science Handbook Math resources Need to know multivariable calculus & linear algebra.

item.title: MITx 6.00.2X: Intro to Computational Thinking and Data Science
item.description: I really liked this class - it was a engaging course to do after having done some intro level stuff. 6.00.2x will teach you how to use computation to accomplish a variety of goals and provides you with a brief introduction to a variety of topics in computational problem solving . This course is aimed at students with some prior programming experience in Python and a rudimentary knowledge of computational complexity.

item.title: Udacity CS101: Intro to CS
item.description: This was one of Udacity’s first computer science MOOC’s, and I really liked it. Its a great fast intro to computer science concepts and python. In particular, I liked that the class both had a cameo by Google’s founder and the final project was to build a simple version of Google’s original search engine using the pagerank algorithim.
